articles.title: About
articles.contents:
About Me
My name is Jihan Bhuiyan, and I am a rising
sophomore at Lexington High School. I am fluent in Python, C++, and
Java, and familiar with a variety of other languages including R, which
was used to make this project. Outside of coding, I am a regular
mountain hiker during the warmer months in New England and a somewhat
active one in the winter.
About the Project
I chose to do a project on monkeypox due to my interest in
epidemiology which was sparked during the COVID-19 pandemic two years
ago, in addition to my desire to help disperse the stigma around who the
virus may possibly be disproportionately affecting. I was also able to
find sufficient data enabling me to do an acceptable level of data
analysis.
Contact Links
GitHub
Project
repository
Email
Credits
This was my final project for the Kane’s Free Data Science
Bootcamp. Consider participating; it will teach you a lot in a very
short time.

articles.title: Age Distribution
articles.description: To analyze the distribution of monkeypox cases by age groups.
articles.contents:
For this plot, I will analyze the distribution of monkeypox cases by
age.



The graph above demonstrates a standard bell-curve distribution, with
cases being most common in adults between their late twenties and early
forties.
Analysis
From this graph one can conclude that adults in their thirties are
most likely to get monkeypox. This is a logical conclusion since one of
the main ways monkeypox spreads is through sexual contact, and people of
this age group are generally the most sexually active. This distribution
will be refined as more data becomes available.

articles.title: Hospitalization Rate
articles.description: To analyze the hospitalization rate of monkeypox.
articles.contents:
For these plots, I am going to compare the hospitalization rates for
monkeypox in countries in North America and Europe, the two main regions
impacted by the outbreak this year. Since the United States and Italy
have the most hospitalization data in their respective regions, I will
use these for my comparison.



This chart demonstrates that the majority of monkeypox cases in the
US so far have not resulted in hospitalization.



This graph shows that just over a simple majority of monkeypox cases
in Italy have resulted in hospitalization. This is over three times as
common as hospitalization in the US.
Analysis
Based on what we see above, one can conclude that hospitalization
from monkeypox is significantly more common in Italy than the US. This
may be due to a variety of factors, including quality of health,
accessibility of healthcare, and the like. However, these numbers are
somewhat crude as of now due to how early it is in the outbreak, and may
be refined over the coming months.

articles.title: An Analysis of Monkeypox Demographics
articles.description: This project will explore some new data about the current monkeypox outbreak.
articles.contents:
At first glance, the current outbreak of monkeypox would appear to be
disproportionately affecting males, with over 95% of confirmed cases
being recorded in such people. The dataset is from Global.health,
compiling individual case data originally from a number of governmental
institutions worldwide. The data was then cleaned up and plotted in a
straightforward manner. While it may appear that monkeypox only impacts
men, this conclusion doesn’t complement past outbreaks, and is possibly
due to deficits in testing.

articles.title: Sources
articles.contents:
The dataset is from Global.health. The raw data can be
found on GitHub.
